comments.body: I would recommend against throwing on errors as it will be 'slower' and more combursome for the user to handle (especially since this function, for example, is not exception safe [it has partially changed the state of the object])

I can certainly make that change. My reasoning was that usually I/O errors are not very strictly handled by upper layers, so if the exception is not handled the program does the right thing and crashes instead of continuing with dodgy data. For instance, I think that `RCsvDS` currently does not strictly distinguish between end-of-file and I/O errors. @dpiparo @bluehood What do you think?

that is indeed up for debate but we are both provide user level interface (unlikely to check results) and framework level interface (likely to check the results, and RDataFrame is a framework using this interface).   I would venture that the error reporting would be better implemented in the RDataFrame layer.
